Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Self-Assembled Conductive Polymer Nanostructures as Coating Additives for Carbon Fiber Reinforced Composite Aircraft
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project aims to demonstrate the feasibility of new nanostructured conductive additives for use in antistatic aerospace high-performance coatings. Static charge buildup from the environment is a critical problem for vehicles which utilize lightweight components constructed from non-conductive plastic or composite materials. Static charge buildup interferes with electronic components, such as distributed sensors, so that mitigation of this effect is essential for safe vehicle operation. This project will characterize and correlate the structure and properties of new conductive polymer nanostructures that are synthesized from inexpensive raw materials and dispersed in organic solvents for direct incorporation into commercial paint formulations. These new additives are based on the synthesis of self-assembling nanostructures from conductive polymers and structure-directing agents. When successfully incorporated in commercial paints and primers, the host's conductive properties are enhanced without compromising adhesion and durability. In this project, the research team will develop technical plans for the scalable and economic synthesis of polymer additives, control and optimize the nanostructure of the additives to maximize conductivity at low concentrations, enhance the electrical conductivity through chemical doping, and demonstrate successful incorporation in commercial coatings while preserving performance specifications.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project relates to enabling the increased adoption of lightweight carbon reinforced composites and plastic structural materials in the aerospace industry. The design of lightweight vehicles using these components, which requires high-performing antistatic coatings, will lead to large reductions in fuel consumption and carbon emissions in transportation. In 2011, emissions from transportation accounted for 28% of U.S. greenhouse gas emissions. Modern aircraft designs, utilizing composite materials, show more than 20% reduction in fuel consumption compared to traditional vehicles. Imminent increases in fuel efficiency standards in automobiles will also drive manufacturers to adopt the use of composite materials. The development of robust antistatic coatings is essential to enabling these new lightweight material technologies. Coatings containing polymer nanostructures will provide improved charge dissipation, reduced weight, improved durability, and will cost less than competing materials. Success in aerospace applications will could also enable the adoption of these technologies in other sectors (e.g. automobile), expanding the economic and ecological benefits and providing follow-on commercial opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The increasingly significant movement across many industries to replace metals with superior plastics is having a positive environmental and economic impact on today’s society. For instance, the production of lighter weight, commercial aircraft has an immediate impact on reducing CO2 emissions, as a result of reduced fuel consumption.

 Most plastics are good insulators, so, therefore, they are not good conductors of electricity. Many applications that specify material conductivity require additives or fillers to meet electrostatic charge dissipation specifications. Electrostatic discharge (ESD) has been, and continues to be, a cause of more than $5 billion dollars of damage to electronic circuitry each year. Currently available conductive metallic additives dramatically sacrifice the specified mechanical and optical properties of coatings in order to more closely match the more critical electrical specifications. End-users are forced to choose between the lesser of two evils and they still end up with a non-conforming material. This STTR project addresses this issue by delivering conforming products with characteristics that result in improved performance, reduced material usage and effective ESD protection.

Conductive polymer additives developed in this STTR project are based on the electroactive capabilities of intrinsically conductive polymers introduced into coatings matrices. During the course of the NSF Phase I STTR grant, PolyDrop was able to develop a new method for the synthesis of organic, solvent-dispersible, conjugated polymers. Quality control metrics were developed in order to ensure the reproducible synthesis of these conductive polymers. The synthesis conditions were then optimized to enhance their nanostructure and conductivity. Additionally, PolyDrop demonstrated multiple processes that may be used to deliver the desired, enhanced conductivity. Finally, PolyDrop demonstrated that these novel materials could be incorporated into commercial coatings in order to meet all customer specifications.

 During this project, our team developed the first, truly flexible, durable, electrostatic-dissipating, polymer additive for coatings that, not only protects the substrate from adverse environmental conditions, but also contributes to a cleaner environment in both its manufacturing and its application.  The incremental benefits of the PolyDrop product include significant reduction in the weight of electrostatic conductive coatings, in the cost for these materials, and in carbon dioxide emissions, resulting, in turn, in a significantly positive impact on the environment.

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2015
Modified by: Volha Hrechka
